Export/import round-trip not fully idempotent for zero values. Consider JSON presence detection or explicit preserve-existing semantics. Location: cmd/bd/import.go:95-106

title: Simplify getNextID SQL query parameters
description: Query passes prefix four times to same SQL query. Works but fragile if query changes. Consider simplifying SQL to require fewer parameters. Location: internal/storage/sqlite/sqlite.go:73-78

title: Add validation/warning for malformed issue IDs

title: Optimize export dependency queries (N+1 problem)
description: Export triggers separate GetDependencyRecords() per issue. For large DBs (1000+ issues), this is N+1 queries. Add GetAllDependencyRecords() to fetch all dependencies in one query. Location: cmd/bd/export.go:52-59, import.go:138-142

title: Add transaction support to storage layer for atomic multi-operation workflows
description: Currently each storage method (CreateIssue, UpdateIssue, etc.) starts its own transaction. This makes it impossible to perform atomic multi-step operations like collision resolution. Add support for passing *sql.Tx through the storage interface, or create transaction-aware versions of methods. This would make remapCollisions and other batch operations truly atomic.

title: Optimize reference updates to avoid loading all issues into memory
description: In updateReferences(), we call SearchIssues with no filter to get ALL issues for updating references. For large databases (10k+ issues), this loads everything into memory. Options: 1) Use batched processing with LIMIT/OFFSET, 2) Use SQL UPDATE with REPLACE() directly, 3) Stream results instead of loading all at once. Located in collision.go:266

title: Cache compiled regexes in replaceIDReferences for performance
description: replaceIDReferences() compiles the same regex patterns on every call. With 100 issues and 10 ID mappings, that's 1000 regex compilations. Pre-compile regexes once and reuse. Can use a struct with compiled regex, placeholder, and newID. Located in collision.go:329. Estimated performance improvement: 10-100x for large batches.

title: Improve error handling in dependency removal during remapping
description: In updateDependencyReferences(), RemoveDependency errors are caught and ignored with continue (line 392). Comment says 'if dependency doesn't exist' but this catches ALL errors including real failures. Should check error type with errors.Is(err, ErrDependencyNotFound) and only ignore not-found errors, returning other errors properly.

title: Use safer placeholder pattern in replaceIDReferences
description: Currently uses bd-313 which could theoretically collide with user text. Use a truly unique placeholder like null bytes: \x00REMAP\x00_0_\x00 which are unlikely to appear in normal text. Located in collision.go:324. Very low probability issue but worth fixing for completeness.

title: Remove unused issueMap in scoreCollisions

title: bd should auto-detect .beads/*.db in current directory
description:
When bd is run without --db flag, it defaults to beads' own database instead of looking for a .beads/*.db file in the current working directory. This causes confusion when working on other projects that use beads for issue tracking (like vc).

Expected behavior: bd should search for .beads/*.db in cwd and use that if found, before falling back to default beads database.

Example: Running 'bd ready' in /Users/stevey/src/vc/vc/ should automatically find and use .beads/vc.db without requiring --db flag every time.

title: Document or automate JSONL sync workflow for git collaboration
description:
When using beads across multiple machines/environments via git, there's a workflow gap:

1. Machine A: Create issues → stored in .beads/project.db
2. Machine A: bd export -o .beads/issues.jsonl
3. Machine A: git add .beads/issues.jsonl && git commit && git push
4. Machine B: git pull
5. Machine B: ??? issues.jsonl exists but project.db is empty/stale

The missing step is: bd import --db .beads/project.db -i .beads/issues.jsonl

This needs to be either:
a) Documented clearly in workflow docs
b) Automated (e.g., git hook, or bd auto-imports if jsonl is newer than db)
c) Both

Real-world impact: User had Claude Code on GCP VM create vc issues from BOOTSTRAP.md. They were exported to issues.jsonl and committed. But on local machine, vc.db was empty until manual import was run.

This prevents .db and .jsonl from getting out of sync, solving the workflow gap where agents forget to run 'bd export'. Can be disabled with --no-auto-flush flag. Addresses bd-32.

title: Add cross-type cycle detection warnings to dependency operations
description: When adding a dependency with 'bd dep add', run DetectCycles() afterwards and warn users if any cycles exist (across all dependency types, not just 'blocks'). This provides visibility into circular dependencies without blocking the operation.
design:
Implementation approach:
1. After successfully adding a dependency in AddDependency, call DetectCycles()
2. If cycles are found, print a warning to stderr showing:
   - The cycle path(s) detected
   - Which dependency types are involved
   - A note that this may cause confusion in dependency visualization
3. Do NOT fail the operation - this is informational only
4. Consider adding a --quiet flag to suppress warnings if needed

The warning should be clear and actionable, e.g.:
WARNING: Circular dependency detected:
  vc-5 (blocks) → vc-13 (parent-child) → vc-5
This may cause confusion in dependency visualization.
acceptance_criteria:
- After 'bd dep add' creates a cross-type cycle, a warning is printed to stderr
- Warning includes the full cycle path with dependency types
- Operation still succeeds (warning only, not an error)
- No warning is printed when no cycles exist
- Warning message is clear and actionable

title: Implement full cross-type cycle prevention in AddDependency
description: Expand cycle prevention in AddDependency to check for cycles across ALL dependency types, not just 'blocks'. Currently only 'blocks' type dependencies are checked for cycles, allowing cross-type circular dependencies to form (e.g., A blocks B, B parent-child A). This can cause semantic confusion and is a maintenance hazard for future operations that traverse dependencies.
design:
Implementation approach:
1. Modify the cycle check in AddDependency (postgres.go:559-599)
2. Remove the 'type = blocks' filter from the recursive CTE
3. Check for cycles regardless of dependency type being added
4. Return a clear error message indicating which types form the cycle

Trade-offs to consider:
- This is more mathematically correct (no cycles in dependency DAG)
- May break legitimate use cases where cross-type cycles are intentional
- Need to evaluate whether ANY cross-type cycles are valid in practice
- Alternative: make this configurable with a --allow-cycle flag

Before implementing, should investigate:
- Are there legitimate reasons for cross-type cycles?
- What's the performance impact on large graphs (1000+ issues)?
- Should certain type combinations be allowed to cycle?
acceptance_criteria:
- AddDependency prevents cycles across all dependency types, not just 'blocks'
- Clear error message when cycle would be created, including dependency types
- All existing tests pass
- Performance benchmarked on large dependency graphs (100+ issues)
- Decision documented on whether to add --allow-cycle flag or exception rules

title: Handle missing JSONL directory in findJSONLPath
description: findJSONLPath() assumes the database directory exists. If someone runs bd init to create a new database but the .beads directory doesn't exist yet, the glob operations might fail silently. Add os.MkdirAll(dbDir, 0755) to ensure directory exists before globbing. Located in cmd/bd/main.go:188-201.

title: Refactor duplicate flush logic in PersistentPostRun
description: PersistentPostRun contains a complete copy of the flush logic instead of calling flushToJSONL(). This violates DRY principle and makes maintenance harder. Refactor to use flushToJSONL() with a force parameter to bypass isDirty check, or extract shared logic into a helper function. Located in cmd/bd/main.go:104-138.

title: Add visibility for auto-flush failures
description: flushToJSONL() writes warnings to stderr when flush fails, but calling code has no way to know if flush succeeded or failed. This means a command could return success even though JSONL is now out of sync. Consider maintaining a 'last flush status' variable or counter for failed flushes, and warn user after multiple consecutive failures (e.g., 3+). Located in cmd/bd/main.go:227-307.

title: Optimize auto-flush to use incremental updates
description: Every flush exports ALL issues and ALL dependencies, even if only one issue changed. For large projects (1000+ issues), this could be expensive. Current approach guarantees consistency, which is fine for MVP, but future optimization could track which issues changed and use incremental updates. Located in cmd/bd/main.go:255-276.

title: Make auto-flush debounce duration configurable
description: flushDebounce is hardcoded to 5 seconds. Make it configurable via environment variable BEADS_FLUSH_DEBOUNCE (e.g., '500ms', '10s'). Current 5-second value is reasonable for interactive use, but CI/automated scenarios might want faster flush. Add getDebounceDuration() helper function. Located in cmd/bd/main.go:31.

title: Add godoc comments for auto-flush functions
description: Add comprehensive godoc comments for findJSONLPath(), markDirtyAndScheduleFlush(), and flushToJSONL() explaining behavior, concurrency considerations, and error handling. Include notes about debouncing behavior (timer resets on each write, flush occurs 5s after LAST operation) and flush-on-exit guarantees. Located in cmd/bd/main.go:188-307.

title: Parent's blocker should block children in ready work calculation
description:
GitHub issue #19: If epic1 blocks epic2, children of epic2 should also be considered blocked when calculating ready work. Currently epic2's children show as ready even though their parent is blocked. This breaks the natural hierarchy of dependencies and can cause agents to work on tasks out of order.

Expected: ready work calculation should traverse up parent-child hierarchy and check if any ancestor has blocking dependencies.

See: https://github.com/anthropics/claude-code/issues/19

title: Add composite index on dependencies(depends_on_id, type)
description:
The hierarchical blocking query does:
JOIN dependencies d ON d.depends_on_id = bt.issue_id
WHERE d.type = 'parent-child'

Currently we only have idx_dependencies_depends_on (line 41 in schema.go), which covers depends_on_id but not the type filter.

**Impact:**
- Query has to scan ALL dependencies for a given depends_on_id, then filter by type
- With 10k+ issues and many dependencies, this could cause slowdowns
- The blocker propagation happens recursively, amplifying the cost

**Solution:**
Add composite index: CREATE INDEX idx_dependencies_depends_on_type ON dependencies(depends_on_id, type)

**Testing:**
Run EXPLAIN QUERY PLAN on GetReadyWork query before/after to verify index usage.

title: Update ready_issues VIEW to use hierarchical blocking
description:
The ready_issues VIEW (schema.go:97-108) uses the OLD blocking logic that doesn't propagate through parent-child hierarchies.

**Problem:**
- GetReadyWork() function now uses recursive CTE with propagation
- But the ready_issues VIEW still uses simple NOT EXISTS check
- Any code using the VIEW will get DIFFERENT results than GetReadyWork()
- This creates inconsistency and confusion

**Impact:**
- Unknown if the VIEW is actually used anywhere in the codebase
- If it is used, it's returning incorrect results (showing children as ready when parent is blocked)

**Solution:**
Either:
1. Update VIEW to match GetReadyWork logic (complex CTE in a view)
2. Drop the VIEW entirely if unused
3. Make VIEW call GetReadyWork as a function (if SQLite supports it)

**Investigation needed:**
Grep for 'ready_issues' to see if the view is actually used.
notes:
**Investigation results:**
Grepped the codebase - the ready_issues VIEW appears in:
- schema.go (definition)
- WORKFLOW.md, DESIGN.md (documentation)
- No actual Go code queries it directly

**Conclusion:** The VIEW is defined but appears UNUSED by actual code. GetReadyWork() function is used instead.

**Recommended solution:** Drop the VIEW entirely to avoid confusion. It serves no purpose if unused and creates a maintenance burden (needs to stay in sync with GetReadyWork logic).

**Alternative:** If we want to keep it for direct SQL access, update the VIEW definition to match the new recursive CTE logic.

title: Add test for deep hierarchy blocking (50+ levels)
description:
Current tests verify 2-level depth (grandparent → parent → child). The depth limit is hardcoded to 50 in the recursive CTE, but we don't test edge cases near that limit.

**Test cases needed:**
1. Verify 50-level deep hierarchy works correctly
2. Verify depth limit prevents runaway recursion
3. Measure performance impact of deep hierarchies
4. Consider if 50 is the right limit (why not 100? why not 20?)

**Rationale:**
- Most hierarchies are 2-5 levels deep
- But pathological cases (malicious or accidental) could create 50+ level nesting
- Need to ensure graceful degradation, not catastrophic failure

**Implementation:**
Add TestDeepHierarchyBlocking to ready_test.go

title: Document hierarchical blocking behavior in README
description:

**What needs documenting:**

3. Note that 'related' and 'discovered-from' do NOT propagate blocking
4. Add example showing epic → child blocking propagation

**Example to add:**
```bash
# If epic is blocked, children are too
bd create "Epic 1" -t epic -p 1
bd create "Task 1" -t task -p 1
bd dep add task-1 epic-1 --type parent-child

# Block the epic
bd create "Blocker" -t task -p 0
bd dep add epic-1 blocker-1 --type blocks

# Now both epic-1 AND task-1 are blocked
bd ready  # Neither will show up
```

title: Add system-wide/multi-repo support for beads

Current limitation: beads is per-repository isolated. Each project has its own .beads/ directory and issues cannot reference issues in other projects.

Potential approaches:
1. Global beads instance in ~/.beads/global.db for cross-project work
2. Project references - allow issues to link across repos
3. Multi-project workspace support - one beads instance managing multiple repos
4. Integration with existing MCP server to provide remote multi-project access

Use cases:
- System administrators tracking work across multiple machines/repos
- Developers working on a dozen+ projects simultaneously
- Cross-cutting concerns that span multiple repositories
- Global todo list with project-specific subtasks

Related:
- GitHub issue #4: https://github.com/steveyegge/beads/issues/4
- Comparison to membank MCP which already supports multi-project via centralized server
- MCP server at integrations/beads-mcp/ could be extended for this

See also: Testing framework for plugins (also from GH #4)

- FindJSONLPath (finds issues.jsonl)
- findDatabaseInTree helper

Label operations:
- AddLabel / RemoveLabel
- GetLabels / GetIssuesByLabel

Events/Comments:
- AddComment
- GetEvents
- GetStatistics

Metadata storage:
- SetMetadata / GetMetadata (used for import hash tracking)

CLI output formatting:
- outputJSON
- printCollisionReport / printRemappingReport
- createIssuesFromMarkdown

**Priority areas:**
1. Auto-flush/import (highest risk - core workflow)
2. Database discovery (second - affects all operations)
3. Labels/events (lower priority - less commonly used)

**Test approach:**
- Add unit tests for dirty tracking in sqlite package
- Add integration tests for auto-flush timing and debouncing
- Add tests for import hash detection and idempotency
- Add tests for database discovery edge cases (permissions, nested dirs)

**Target:** Get overall coverage from 60% → 75%, focus on cmd/bd (currently 24.1%)

**Note:** These features work well in practice (dogfooding proves it) but edge cases (disk full, permissions, concurrent access, race conditions) are untested.

title: Investigate vector/semantic search for issue discovery
description:
From GH issue #2 RFC discussion: Evaluate if vector/semantic search over issues would provide value for beads.

**Use case:** Find semantically related issues (e.g., 'login broken' finds 'authentication failure', 'session expired').

**Questions to answer:**
1. What workflows would this enable that we can't do now?
2. Is dataset size (typically 50-200 issues) large enough to benefit?
3. Do structured features (deps, tags, types) already provide better relationships?
4. What's the maintenance cost (embeddings, storage, recomputation)?

**Alternatives to consider:**
- Improve 'bd list' filtering with regex/boolean queries
- Add 'bd related <id>' showing deps + mentions + same tags
- Export to JSON and pipe to external AI tools

**Decision:** Only implement if clear use case emerges. Don't add complexity for theoretical benefits.

**Context:** Part of evaluating Turso RFC ideas (GH #2). Vector search was proposed but unclear if needed for typical beads usage.

title: Implement storage driver interface for pluggable backends
description:
Create abstraction layer for storage to support multiple backends (SQLite, Postgres, Turso, in-memory testing, etc.).

**Current state:** All storage logic hardcoded to SQLite in internal/storage/sqlite/sqlite.go

**Proposed design:**

```go
// internal/storage/storage.go
type Store interface {
    // Issue CRUD
    CreateIssue(issue *Issue) error
    GetIssue(id string) (*Issue, error)
    UpdateIssue(id string, updates *Issue) error
    DeleteIssue(id string) error
    ListIssues(filter *Filter) ([]*Issue, error)
    
    // Dependencies
    AddDependency(from, to string, depType DependencyType) error
    RemoveDependency(from, to string, depType DependencyType) error
    GetDependencies(id string) ([]*Dependency, error)
    
    // Counters, stats
    GetNextID(prefix string) (string, error)
    GetStats() (*Stats, error)
    
    Close() error
}
```

**Benefits:**
- Better testing (mock/in-memory stores)
- Future flexibility (Postgres, cloud APIs, etc.)
- Clean architecture (business logic decoupled from storage)
- Enable Turso or other backends without refactoring everything

**Implementation steps:**
1. Define Store interface in internal/storage/storage.go
2. Refactor SQLiteStore to implement interface
3. Update all commands to use interface, not concrete type
4. Add MemoryStore for testing
5. Add driver selection via config (storage.driver = sqlite|turso|postgres)
6. Update tests to use interface

**Note:** This is valuable even without adopting Turso. Good architecture practice.

**Context:** From GH issue #2 RFC evaluation. Driver interface is low-cost, high-value regardless of whether we add alternative backends.

title: Investigate auto-export debounce not triggering
description:
Auto-export to JSONL did not trigger automatically after creating bd-72 and bd-73. Had to manually run 'bd export' to sync.

**Expected behavior:** Auto-export should trigger ~5 seconds after CRUD operations (per CLAUDE.md documentation).

**Actual behavior:** Issues bd-72 and bd-73 were created but JSONL was not updated until manual 'bd export' was run.

**Investigation needed:**
1. Check if auto-flush goroutine is running
2. Verify debounce timer is being triggered on CreateIssue()
3. Check for errors/panics in background export
4. Verify auto-flush is enabled by default
5. Check if there's a race condition with shutdown

**Impact:** HIGH - Data loss risk if users create issues and don't realize they haven't synced to Git.

**Testing:**
```bash
# Create issue and wait 10 seconds
bd create "Test" -p 4
sleep 10
grep "Test" .beads/issues.jsonl  # Should find it
```

**Workaround:** Manually run 'bd export' after CRUD operations.

**Context:** Discovered during GH issue #2 RFC evaluation while creating bd-72 and bd-73.

title: Add --show-all-paths flag to bd dep tree

title: Make maxDepth configurable in bd dep tree command

title: Refactor parseMarkdownFile to reduce cyclomatic complexity
description: The parseMarkdownFile function in cmd/bd/markdown.go has a cyclomatic complexity of 38, which exceeds the recommended threshold of 30. This makes the function harder to understand, test, and maintain.
design:
Split the function into smaller, focused units:

1. parseMarkdownFile(filepath) - Main entry point, handles file I/O
2. parseMarkdownContent(scanner) - Core parsing logic
3. processIssueSection(issue, section, content) - Handle section finalization (current switch statement)
4. parseLabels(content) []string - Extract labels from content
5. parseDependencies(content) []string - Extract dependencies from content
6. parsePriority(content) int - Parse and validate priority

Benefits:
- Each function has a single responsibility
- Easier to test individual components
- Lower cognitive load when reading code
- Better encapsulation of parsing logic
acceptance_criteria:
- parseMarkdownFile complexity < 15
- New helper functions each have complexity < 10
- All existing tests still pass
- No change in functionality or behavior
- Code coverage maintained or improved
